info.name: Spark.re
info.description:
Spark powers new development real estate

Spark is a sales, marketing, and customer relationship management platform designed specifically for the new development/pre-sale real estate industry.

Follow along with this documentation to learn about how to use the API and contact us at support@spark.re if you have any further questions.

Getting Started

The Spark API is a RESTful interface, providing programmatic access to much of the data in the platform. It provides predictable URLs for accessing resources, and uses built-in HTTP features to receive requests and return responses.

Keep in mind that this documention assumes some basic understanding of how to work with APIs, including the requirement to percent/url encode all URLs before submitting requests.

Environments

Spark has a few publically accessible environments, while most of the time you'll want to work with the production environment, if you've been given access to to our demo environment (which is usually the case if you're testing/building a new integration), you'll need to prefix all of the domains with "demo".

For example:

  • https://spark.re becomes https://demo.spark.re

  • https://app.spark.re becomes https://demo-app.spark.re

  • https://api.spark.re becomes https://demo-api.spark.re

Note: If you're using the Postman collection & environment, you only need to update the initial and current values, not the variable name. This allows you to easily switch between the demo and production environment.

Understanding the Data

Companies & Projects

Data in Spark is stored and returned at 2 levels. You are able to create an API key at a company or project level, and depending on the which is submitted with the request, you will receive different data in return:

Company

A company is a real estate developer, marketing firm, or brokerage using the Spark platform. All of our data is separated on a per company basis.

When accessing the API using a company API key, it will return data for all of the projects that belong to it.

Project

A project is an indivdual real estate development, usually a single building that is being sold or leased. All projects belong to a single company, but a company can have multiple projects.

When accessing the API using a project API key, it will only return data for that project.

Formats

Dates & Times

All dates and times are returned following the ISO 8601 standard, in UTC (referred to as Z, meaning zero offset):

"created_at": "2023-03-02T20:17:00Z"

Money

All monetary values are returned in cents:

"purchase_price": 142679200

Prices and other monetary values will need to be converted by moving the decimal place based on the currency you are working with.

For example, to convert to a currency that has 2 decimal places, (like USD/CAD), divide the value by 100.

Authorization

Warning !@#&

The Spark API should only ever be accessed from the server side (aka backend) component of an application. Accessing the API from the client side (such as using javascript that is executed in a web browser) will expose the API key, and could allow access to all of the company and project data within Spark. You are responsible for connecting to the API, and storing credentials in a secure way.

Authorization Header

Spark uses an HTTP token authorization for API access. An API key can be generated from a Spark account under Settings -> API. If you don't have access to Spark, ask your company contact to provide you with an account, or an API key with the correct permissions (see below).

An authorization header should be submitted with all requests, in the following format:

Authorization: Token token="•••••••"

Note: The authorization header has been set on the top level of the Spark.re collection in Postman, and is inherited on all API requests automatically. There is no need to manually add it to each Postman request.

Example:

curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts' \
     --header 'Authorization: Token token="•••••••"'

API Key Permissions

When API keys are generated in Spark, they should be given the minimum required permissions to return only the data required for the integration.

If an integration only requires access to read or write Contacts, please don't give access to read Inventory, Contracts, Reservations, Projects, etc.

Note: You don't need read permissions on data if you are only writing data. When a Create or Update request is sent, just as long as it was successful, you will get the result back in the response.

Pagination

When a response from the API includes many results, Spark will paginate them and return a subset. By default, Spark will return 25 results per page.

For example, GET /v2/contacts (Get Contacts) will only return 25 contacts even though the database can include many thousands of contacts. This makes the response quicker and easier to handle.

When a response is paginated, the response headers will include a Link header. The link header will be omitted if the endpoint does not support pagination or if all results fit on a single page. The link header contains URLs that you can used to fetch additional pages of results.

curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts'

If the response is paginated, the link header will look something like:

Link: <https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?page=2>; rel="last", <https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?page=2>; rel="next"

The link header provides the URL for the previous, next, first, and last page of results:

  • The URL for the previous page is followed by rel="prev".

  • The URL for the next page is followed by rel="next".

  • The URL for the first page is followed by rel="first".

  • The URL for the last page is followed by rel="last".

In some cases, only a subset of these links are available. For example, the link to the previous page won't be included if you are on the first page of results, and the link to the last page won't be included if it can't be calculated.

You can use the URLs from the link header to request another page of results. For example, to request the next page of results based on the previous example:

curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?page=2'

Results Per Page

Most endpoints accept a per_page query parameter to control how many results are returned on a page. The maximum results permitted per page is 100.

For example, this request submits the per_page query parameter to return five results per page:

curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?per_page=5'

When the per_page parameter is submitted, it will be included in the response link header:

Link: <https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?page=2&per_page=5>; rel="last", <https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?page=2&per_page=5>; rel="next"

Request Parameters

When submitting a request that includes query parameters for filtering & ordering, the response link header will include them.

For example, this request submits the first_name_cont query parameter to return contacts who's first name contains John:

curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?first_name_cont=John'

When the first_name_cont parameter is submitted, it will be included in the response link header:

Link: <https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?page=2&first_name_cont=John>; rel="last", <https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?page=2&first_name_cont=John>; rel="next"

Filtering

When looking at the endpoints listed in this documentation, there will be query parameters listed (ending with _#) when that endpoint supports filters. The listed query parameters are meant to outline commonly used filters, however almost every field returned in the results can be used for filtering.

When using the listed query params, you simply need to replace the _# with one of the modifiers below. A few examples of this may be:

  • rating_value_# → rating_value_eq

  • city_# → city_start

  • first_name_# → first_name_cont

Modifier Description Works with field types
_eq Equals boolean, float, integer, date, datetime, string
_not_eq Does not equal boolean, float, integer, date, datetime, string
_cont Contains float, integer, date, datetime, string
_not_cont Does not contain float, integer, date, datetime, string
_null Has no value float, integer, date, datetime, string
_not_null Has a value float, integer, date, datetime, string
_lt Less than float, integer, date, datetime
_lteq Less than or equal to float, integer, date, datetime
_gt Greater than float, integer, date, datetime
_gteq Greater than or equal to float, integer, date, datetime
_start Starts with float, integer, date, datetime, string
_not_start Does not start with float, integer, date, datetime, string
_end Ends with float, integer, date, datetime, string
_not_end Does not end with float, integer, date, datetime, string

To use non listed filter, provide a field name (aka key) along with an modifier from the list below. The modifiers should added to the end of the field name.

For example, looking at a partial contact object from the GET /v2/contacts (Get Contacts) request has email , first_name, andcreated_at fields.

{
    ~~~
    "created_at": "2023-02-24T03:32:37Z",
    "date_of_birth": null,
    "email": "john@sparkreexample.com",
    "fax": null,
    "first_name": "John",
    ~~~
}

To filter the results you can pass the parameters in the following formats to achieve the result noted in the comments below:

// Email must exactly match john@sparkreexample.com
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?email_eq=john@sparkreexample.com'
// First name must contain John
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?first_name_cont=John'
// Contact was created on or after March 2nd
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?created_at_gteq=2023-03-02'

Matching Multiple Values

There may be cases where you want results that match multiple values for the same query parameter. All of the modifiers above (except _null and _not_null) can be used with an additional _any modifier.

When using the any modifier, you will need to submit the query parameter name (aka key) as an array, by appending [] to the end. A few examples of this may be:

  • rating_value_eq → rating_value_eq_any[]

  • city_eq → city_eq_any[]

  • first_name_cont → first_name_cont_any[]

Those filters in action:

// Has Hot or Warm rating
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?rating_value_eq_any[]=Hot&rating_value_eq_any[]=Warm'
// Lives within New York or New Jersey
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?city_eq_any[]=New+York&city_eq_any[]=New+Jersey'
// Has first name that contains John, Jane, or Jim
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?first_name_cont_any[]=John&first_name_cont_any[]=Jane&first_name_cont_any[]=Jim'

Combining Multiple Parameters

Multiple query parameters can be separated by &, which then filters down the results further. Each query parameter is appened with AND, meaning the results will only match all of the filters requested.

For example, you can filter the results to only return Contacts with a first_name of John in the city of New York:

curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?first_name_cont=John&city_eq=New+York'

Additional Examples

See the example requests included in this documentation for additional examples of how to use the filters.

Ordering

There are query parameters on each endpoint that supports ordering (aka sorting). Most fields returned in the the results can be used for ordering. A direction can also be provided to change which results are returned first.

Note: The fields that are supported must be a direct child of a parent object that is returned, ordering based on nested fields is not currently supported. If you want to sort based on nested fields, make a request with the required order to those endpoints.

Field Selection

The results are ordered by created_at by default. This in combination with a default decending direction means that the newest result will always be returned first, and the oldest last.

To order the results, submit the order query parameter along with the name of a field as the value.

// Order by id
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?order=id'
// Order by last_name
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?order=last_name'
// Order by registered_at
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?order=registered_at'

Direction

The results are ordered in decending (desc) order by default, which returns Z-A 9-0. You can also sort ascending (asc) which returns A-Z 0-9.

To change the direction, submit the order, and direction query parameters.

// Order by id ascending
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?order=id&direction=asc'
// Order by last_name ascending
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?order=last_name&direction=asc'
// Order by registered_at descending
curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts?order=registered_at&direction=desc'

GET

Querying for a list of records returns a limited dataset for all records. This includes model attributes and foreign keys. These records can be further refined with the use of filters.

Querying for a single record returns the most complete dataset. All model attributes and associations are returned with their own attributes and foreign keys.

Create & Update

For all create (via POST) or update (via PUT) requests, you will need to keep the following requirements in mind:

Company API key vs Project API key

Our API only supports creating or updating data from a project api key. This means if you're working with a company api key, you will get an error when submitting the request. We will be supporting these request types from a company api key in the near future.

Content Type

Spark accepts data for processing in JSON format. A header should be submitted with all create or update requests, in the following format:

Content-Type: application/json

Note: The content type header is set automatically in Postman as part of the request. The body is set to pass in raw text in JSON. There is no need to manually add it to each Postman request.

Example:

curl --location 'https://api.spark.re/v2/contacts' \
     --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
     --data-raw '{ "email": "john@sparkreexample.com" }'

Date & Time Formats

All dates and times are accepted following the ISO 8601 standard. The following dates and times are all considered the same, and will be processed regardless of the format provided.

Description Format
Date 2023-03-02
Date and time 2023-03-02T00:00:00
Date and time in compressed format 20230302T000000
Date and time with miliseconds 2023-03-02T00:00:00.000
Date and time in UTC 2023-03-02T00:00:00Z
Date and time with timezone 2023-03-02T00:00:00+00:00

Note: If a date is submitted where a date and time is expected, the time will be set to 00:00.

Timezones

Dates & times in Spark are stored in UTC, so if a timezone is not specified, it will assume you've converted to UTC before submission. If a timezone is specified, Spark will adjust the time to UTC before saving the value.

If the following datetime with a timezone offset of -8 (PST) is passed, when saved and returned in UTC it will have been adjusted to the next day.

2023-03-02T17:25:50-08:00 → 2023-03-03T01:25:50Z

ID vs. Page Location

For certain API integrations, it is highly recommend to use the ID endpoint (if available) instead of page location. Update (via PUT) requests that targets ID can reduce the likelihood of issues as page locations can change over time during a project's lifespan.

Status Codes

Responses from the Spark API will return one of the following status codes:

Code Description
200 Success Everything worked as expected
201 Created Entity was created
400 Bad Request The request format was incorrect - Often a required parameter is missing, or the JSON format is incorrect.
401 Unauthorized No valid API key provided
402 Request Failed Parameters were valid but request failed
404 Not Found The requested item doesn’t exist
422 Unprocessable Entity The request format was correct but could not be processed - Often a referenced ID is not valid
500, 502, 503, 504 Server Errors - Something is wrong on Spark's end

item.name: API v2
Additional Fields

description.content: [integer] Which page of results to return
[integer] The number of results returned per page. Defaults to 25
[string] Provide a field name to change the sort order. Defaults to created_at
[string] Accepts asc or desc. Defaults to desc

item.description:
An additional field is a non Spark default, custom field that can be used with contacts, contracts, inventory, reservations, and team members.

An additional field on a object (like contacts) can either be associated with a standardized field, or can be a one off value.

item.name: Custom Fields

description.content: [integer] Which page of results to return
[integer] The number of results returned per page. Defaults to 25
[string] Provide a field name to change the sort order. Defaults to created_at
[string] Accepts asc or desc. Defaults to desc

request.description:
A POST request to create a new custom field. The custom field's name, category and input_type are required to create a new custom field.

See the POST /v2/custom-fields (Create Custom Field) Body for a list of available fields, and the expected format for submitting values.

item.description:
A custom field is a non Spark default attribute that can be used with contacts, contracts, brokerage, inventory, reservations, and team members.

A custom field on an object (like contacts) is associated to the owner record and stores it's value on the record as a custom_field_value

When using a Company API Key:

  • Creates a Custom Field at the company level.

  • If the field is for Contacts, Brokerages, or Team Members, it is automatically shared across all projects.

  • If the field is for Inventory or Contracts, it is not shared by default and must be explicitly shared with projects through the UI.

When using a Project API Key:

  • Creates a Custom Field only at the project level.

  • These fields remain exclusive to the project and cannot be shared across projects.

item.name: Brokerages

description.content: [integer] Which page of results to return
[integer] The number of results returned per page. Defaults to 25
[string] Provide a field name to change the sort order. Defaults to created_at
[string] Accepts asc or desc. Defaults to desc

request.description:
A POST request to create a new brokerage. Only a name is required to create a new brokerage although we recommended you include as much information as you have available.

See the POST /v2/brokerages (Create Brokerage) Body for a list of available fields, and the expected format for submitting values.

item.description: A brokerage is a company that a real estate agent works for, and is the recipient of external commissions on a contract or reservation.

item.name: Company
item.description: A company is the real estate developer, marketing firm, or brokerage who is using our platform.

item.name: Contact Groups

description.content: [integer] Which page of results to return
[integer] The number of results returned per page. Defaults to 25
[string] Provide a field name to change the sort order. Defaults to created_at
[string] Accepts asc or desc. Defaults to desc

request.description: A GET request to find a contact by email.

item.description: A contact group is a group of contacts.

item.name: Contact Ratings

description.content: [integer] Which page of results to return
[integer] The number of results returned per page. Defaults to 25
[string] Provide a field name to change the sort order. Defaults to created_at
[string] Accepts asc or desc. Defaults to desc

request.description: A GET request to find a contact rating by id.

item.description: A contact rating is assigned to a contact to classify their potential to purchase a unit.

item.name: Contacts

description.content: [integer] Which page of results to return
[integer] The number of results returned per page. Defaults to 25
[string] Provide a field name to change the sort order. Defaults to created_at
[string] Accepts asc or desc. Defaults to desc

request.description:
Note: The create endpoint does not work with a company API key.

A POST request to create a new contact. Only an email or phone is required to create a new contact although we recommended you include as much information as you have available.

If a contact is submitted with an email address that already exists in the database, it will update the existing contact with the submitted details.

See the POST /v2/contacts (Create Contact) Body for a list of available fields, and the expected format for submitting values.

Note: The update endpoint does not work with a company API key.

A PUT request to update a specific contact by ID.

See the POST /v2/contacts (Create Contact) Body for a list of available fields, and the expected format for submitting values.

item.description: A contact is a registrant, lead, or person that is interested in, or has purchased a unit with the project or company. These contacts can self register, be imported, or transfered from another project.

item.name: Contracts

request.description: A GET request to find a contact by email.

description.content: [integer] Which page of results to return
[integer] The number of results returned per page. Defaults to 25
[string] Provide a field name to change the sort order. Defaults to created_at
[string] Accepts asc or desc. Defaults to desc

item.description: A contract is a legally binding document that outlines terms, conditions, exchanges and payment between two parties in a real estate transaction.

item.description: A deposit is a monitary amount that is provided at the time of contract acceptance as consideration for the sale. All amounts get put toward the final amount owed at closing.

request.description:
Note: The create endpoint does not work with a company API key.

A POST request to create a new event. A title, kind, start, and end date are required to create a new event although we recommended you include as much information as you have available.

See the POST /v2/events (Create Event) Body for a list of available fields, and the expected format for submitting values.

item.description: An event in a team members calendar.

request.description:
Note: The create endpoint does not work with a company API key.

A POST request to create a new contact. A contact_id, interaction_type_id, team_member_id, and timestamp are required to create a new interaction although we recommended you include as much information as you have available.

See the POST /v2/interactions (Create Interaction) Body for a list of available fields, and the expected format for submitting values.

item.description: An interaction is logged by team members when engaging with a contact via email, phone, in person or virtually.

request.description:
Note: The create endpoint does not work with a company API key.

A POST request to create a new note. The notes text and a team_member_id, along with any one of contact_id, contract_id, interaction_id, or inventory_id are required to create a new note.

See the POST /v2/notes (Create Note) Body for a list of available fields, and the expected format for submitting values.

item.description: A note is used by team members to log specific details about an contact, interaction, inventory, contract, or reservation.

item.description:
An standardized field is a non Spark default, custom field that can be used with contacts, contracts, inventory, reservations, and team members.

An additional field on a object (like contacts) can either be associated with a standardized field, or can be a one off value.

item.description: A user, or team member as they are referred to in Spark has access to the application, and takes actions on the various resources.

Spark's Current API

Spark's new API released in 2023, v2 is a complete rewrite from the ground up and gives access to more data than ever before.
